results.title: The Tree. - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: Edward Schuman, Dimension Films and Michael Ahnemann
results.brief_description: This film describes the beauty of trees and their importance to birds, insects, other plants, animals and people. It introduces the interdependence of living things. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: The Tree. - 1st ed.
results.creator_credit: Dimension Films, Churchill Films and Michael Murphy
results.brief_description: This film describes the beauty of trees, and introduces simple ideas of ecology. Living things depend on each other; a tree is important to the community of birds, insects, plants and animals living around it. Written by Edward Schuman. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: The Tree that remembers (D)
results.brief_description: In 1992 a young Iranian student and an ex-prisoner of war under the Ayatollah’s regime during the 80’s, hanged himself on the outskirts of a small town in Canada. Director Masoud Raouf, also an ex-prisoner under the Ayatollah regime has sought to address and understand the inherent long-term issues surrounding the survival of ex-political prisoners and asylum seekers, raising issues of cultural integration and disparity between Western cultures and refugees generally whilst giving air to subjects usually silent within Western communities. A group of former prisoners in Iran elucidate on their personal experiences describing the horrors of torture and imprisonment and the means in which they survived spiritually throughout their detainment. “Boxing” a form of solitary confinement is described in detail with its psychological effect - a form of torture that mimics the corpse in order to break the spirit.

results.title: The Tree outside my house
results.brief_description:
The concept of the project was to represent the process of establishing data. The data was established as a set of 20 facts about the tree outside my house. The representations of the processes were to be strongly associated with my memories of learning and using these processes.
Initially the concept of the project only dealt with the
visualisation of the height of the tree and the process to
establish that fact. The visualisation of this process was to
be based on my childhood memories of a school activity.
The initial concept was later widened to include 20 facts
about the tree.
I was more interested in the processes used to establish
the facts than the facts themselves. I wanted to explore my memories and visually represent the process as a memory. The processes I wanted to represent were tied to the following facts:
•The name of the tree
•The botanical name of the tree
•The distance from the tree
•The angle to the top of the tree
•The height equals distance multiplied by pi
•The height of the tree
•The width of the trunk
•The volume of the tree
•The age of the tree
•The colour of the bark in RGB
•The colour of the bark in hexadecimal
•The bark’s range and difference of colours
•The shape of the leaves
•The colour of the leaves
•The size of the leaves
•The area of the leaves
•The noise of the wind in the leaves of the tree
•The number of branches
•The location of the tree

results.title: The tree of truth
results.creator_credit: Davidson Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
The story of a land with a magic tree that provides true or false answers to any problem posed. The king poses a question about wealth - experts disagree as to whether it is an addition or a sub-traction problem, although the tree maintains both methods are acceptable.
Previewing is essential. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: The Tree of life
results.creator_credit: Harold Cooper, Lintas Film Unit and Gerard De Boe
results.brief_description: The discovery, harvesting and preparation of palm oil in the Belgian Congo. Something of the history of the industry, the concession given to Lever Bros by King Leopold and the transportation difficulties in penetrating the interior of the Congo are shown.

results.title: The Tree house
results.brief_description: Asks if man can live in the world without oblierating its beauty. Shows how a bulldozer driver befriends a young boy who has built a treehouse on the edge of a site the man has to clear. Ends with the driver unable to tell the boy why his tree has to come down.

results.title: The Tree
results.creator_credit: International Council for Education Media and Georg Schimanski
results.brief_description: Time-lapse photography helps us appreciate the marvellous seasonal changes undergone by a large oak tree. These changes also affect the many animals and insects that feed and live in the tree. Among other things, the film describes how the tree nourishes itself during the growing season, how it synthesizes various elements during the day and at night. The tree and the creatures who inhabit it form an impressive microcosm, kept in good health by natural checks and balances.
